<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27PT">
	For the year ended April 30, 2016, gross margin decreased as a result of lower revenues, however gross margin rate increased.&#160; The increase in gross margin rate was mainly a result of increase in efficiencies due to the completion of the implementation of automated test equipment as mentioned below, reduction in costs and product mix at FEI-NY.&#160; The other factor increasing gross margin rate is the increase in revenues at FEI-Zyfer, which had a larger impact in consolidated results. For the year ended April 30, 2015, gross margin and the gross margin rate decreased over the prior fiscal year due to product mix, higher than anticipated contract costs and inventory-related charges.&#160; Exceptional engineering costs incurred late in the fiscal year, related to delivery of state-of-the-art satellite systems as well as efforts to increase production capacity in the FEI-NY segment resulted in inefficiencies and higher costs.&#160; Higher contract costs were pronounced on one program with an aggregate contract value of approximately $27 million.&#160; This program requires a relatively high quantity of units to be manufactured for which automated processes were implemented during fiscal year 2015.&#160; Higher than anticipated touch labor was incurred while those processes and related equipment were being installed, increasing the expected costs on the program&#8217;s contracts by approximately $2 million.&#160; The net gross margin on these contracts recognized during fiscal year 2015 was a loss of $800,000.&#160; Over the life of the contracts through April 30, 2015, the Company recorded net gross margin of approximately $2.5 million.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
	&#160;
</FONT>
	In future years, the Company expects to realize improved margins from this investment in capacity improvements and to generate additional satellite business from its enhanced technological capabilities.&#160; Inventory write downs at several subsidiaries which aggregated approximately $800,000 and increased costs of approximately $450,000 recorded in the Gillam-FEI segment combined to reduce the gross margin rate by 1.6%.&#160; The Gillam-FEI costs are for the purpose of modifying certain network infrastructure inventory originally manufactured for the U.S. market to be able to sell the same units in non-U.S. markets.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	15
</FONT>
</DIV>

	Selling and Administrative Expenses

<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP" VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2">
	&#160;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; PADDING-BOTTOM: 2PX; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; WIDTH: 1.23%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" NOWRAP="NOWRAP">
	&#160;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP" VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="3">
	&#160;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27PT">
	In the fiscal years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015, selling and administrative costs (&#8220;SG&amp;A&#8221;) were 22% and 19%, respectively, of consolidated revenues.&#160; For fiscal year 2016, incentive compensation expense decreased from the prior year due to reduced operating profits. Selling and administrative expenses include stock compensation expense of $548,000 and $668,000, respectively.&#160; The Company expects fiscal year 2017 selling and administrative expenses to meet or approach our target of 20% of revenues.
</DIV>

	&#160;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27PT">
	Research and development (&#8220;R&amp;D&#8221;) expenditures represent investments intended to keep the Company&#8217;s products at the leading edge of time and frequency technology and enhance competitiveness for future revenues.&#160; As a percentage of consolidated revenue, R&amp;D spending for the years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015 was approximately 10% and 7%, respectively. During fiscal year 2016, the Company has continued the development of its frequency converter product line in particular (the following letters represent specific frequency bands) Ku to Ku band converters, Ka to Ka band converters and new Ka to L band and L to Ka band converters. Internal R&amp;D spending will also include, additional work on Low noise CRO&#8217;s and low aging, and high stability Rb standard for secure communications.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The Company also continued to engage in customer-funded development activity, the cost of which appears in cost of revenues, thus reducing the level of internal R&amp;D spending.&#160; Although funding is obtained from customers, the Company retains the rights to any products developed.&#160; The Company will continue to devote significant resources to develop new products, enhance existing products and implement efficient manufacturing processes.&#160; For fiscal year 2017, the Company anticipates that internal research and development spending will be comparable to the amount expended during fiscal year 2016 but will remain at less than 10% of revenues.&#160; The Company believes that internally generated cash and cash reserves are adequate to fund these development efforts.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	For fiscal year ended April 30, 2016 the combination of SG&amp;A and R&amp;D expenses were down approximately 4% compared to prior fiscal year. Thus, the decrease in operating profit in fiscal year 2016 is mainly due to lower gross margin as discussed above.&#160; Both the FEI-NY and FEI-Zyfer segments recorded operating profits, however the FEI-NY segment was down from last year in each of FEI-Elcom, FEI-Asia and FEI-NY itself.&#160; This was offset by an over 100% increase in operating profit at the FEI-Zyfer segment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	For the year ended April 30, 2015, the combination of SG&amp;A and R&amp;D expenses were approximately the same as that spent in the prior fiscal year.&#160; Thus, the decrease in operating profit in fiscal year 2015 is entirely due to lower gross margin as discussed above.&#160; Both the FEI-NY and FEI-Zyfer segments recorded operating profits which were offset by operating losses at the Gillam-FEI segment.
</DIV>

<DIV>

</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	Investment income is derived primarily from the Company&#8217;s holdings of marketable securities.&#160; Earnings on these securities may vary based on fluctuating dividend payout levels and interest rates and the timing of purchases or sales of securities.&#160; During fiscal years 2016 and 2015, investment income included gains upon the sale or redemption of marketable securities of approximately $131,000 and $566,000, respectively.&#160; During fiscal year 2017, the Company anticipates that investment income will be approximately the same as that earned in fiscal year 2016, depending on the yield and size of its investment portfolio and the timing of any sales or redemptions of marketable securities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	In fiscal year 2016, interest expense was incurred on borrowings under the Company&#8217;s $25 million credit facility with a bank and on deferred compensation payments.&#160; During fiscal year 2016, interest expense relating to the line of credit was lower as compared to the prior fiscal year, offset by an increase in deferred compensation payments.&#160; Interest expense in future years will be dependent on interest rates in the U.S. and the level of the Company&#8217;s borrowings under the credit facility.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27PT">
	During fiscal year 2016, other income included approximately $380,000 from the proceeds of a life insurance policy of a former officer of the Corporation. During fiscal year 2015, other income consisted of insignificant non-operating expenses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27PT">

</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	For the year ended April 30, 2016, the provision for taxes was lower than the prior year due to lower pre-tax income.&#160; The effective tax rate increased due to increased pre-tax losses incurred at the Company&#8217;s foreign subsidiaries for which it receives no tax benefit.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company is subject to taxation in several countries.&#160; The statutory federal rates are 34% in the U.S., 33% in Europe and 25% in China.&#160; The Company utilizes the availability of research and development tax credits (&#8220;R&amp;D credit&#8221;) in the U.S. to lower its tax rate.&#160; (See Note 12 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for a reconciliation of the actual tax benefit to the expected tax provision at the federal statutory rate.)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	The Company&#8217;s European subsidiaries have available net operating loss (&#8220;NOL&#8221;) carryforwards of approximately $6.4 million to offset future taxable income.&#160; The associated deferred tax asset for the foreign subsidiary NOL is fully reserved by the deferred tax valuation allowance.&#160; These loss carryforwards have no expiration date.&#160; As a result of the acquisition of FEI-Elcom, the Company has a federal NOL carryforward of $4.4 million which may be applied in annually limited amounts to offset future U.S.-sourced taxable income over the next 15 years.
</DIV>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<U>
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	The Company&#8217;s balance sheet continues to reflect a highly liquid position with working capital of $75.6 million at April 30, 2016.&#160; Included in working capital at April 30, 2016 is $17.2 million consisting of cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments.&#160; The Company&#8217;s current ratio at April 30, 2016 is 9.6 to 1 compared to 10.0 to 1 at the end of the prior fiscal year.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	17
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage18"></A>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEHEADER" STYLE="WIDTH: 100%">
<A HREF="#FREQUENCYELE10K043016_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	Net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended April 30, 2016, was $2.9 million compared to $1.9 million for the prior fiscal year.&#160; During fiscal years 2016 and 2015, the Company incurred $3.1 million and $4.3 million, respectively, in non-cash charges to earnings, including depreciation and amortization expense, inventory write downs, warranty and accounts receivable reserves, certain employee benefit plan expenses, including accounting for stock-based compensation.&#160; During fiscal year 2016, operating cash was reduced by increases to inventory offset by a decrease to accounts receivables.&#160; For fiscal year 2015, operating cash was reduced by increases to accounts receivable and reductions in accrued expenses and other liabilities.&#160; In fiscal year 2017, the Company anticipates that it will maintain positive cash flow from operations by continuing to generate operating profits and managing its inventory levels.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	Net cash used in investing activities for the fiscal year ended April 30, 2016 was $3.5 million compared to cash provided of $1.2 million in fiscal year 2015.&#160; In fiscal year 2016, investing activities included net uses from the redemption, sale or purchase of marketable securities for $89,000 and acquisitions of capital equipment and other long term assets for $3.4 million.&#160; In fiscal year 2015 investing activities consisted of net proceeds from the redemption, sale or purchase of marketable securities of $5.3 million and acquisitions of capital equipment and other long term assets for $4.1 million.&#160; The Company may continue to invest cash equivalents in longer-term securities or to convert short-term investments to cash equivalents as dictated by its investment and acquisition strategies.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The Company has a five-year, $25 million credit facility from a bank.&#160; As of April 30, 2016, the Company has an outstanding balance of $6.0 million under the credit facility.&#160; &#160; During fiscal year 2015, as certain marketable securities were sold or redeemed and as the Company generated positive operating cash flow, the Company paid down a portion of the credit facility as indicated in the next paragraph.&#160; The Company may draw on this bank credit facility to provide additional working capital and to fund acquisitions.&#160; The interest rate on the credit facility is based on LIBOR plus either 75 basis points or 175 basis points depending on under which of the two tranches the Company chooses to borrow.&#160; For a more complete description of the credit facility, see Note 7 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.&#160; In addition, the Company&#8217;s European subsidiaries have available approximately $275,000 under a bank credit line to meet short-term cash flow requirements.&#160; The rate of interest on any borrowings is based on the one-month EURO Interbank Offered Rate (EURIBOR).&#160; The European subsidiaries had no borrowings against this line of credit during fiscal year 2016.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	During the year ended April 30, 2016, cash provided by financing activities was $141,000 consisting of the tax benefit arising from the exercise of stock-based awards.&#160; There were no additional borrowings or payments made under the bank credit facility. During the year ended April 30, 2015, cash used in financing activities was $3.9 million.&#160; The Company borrowed $2.3 million under its bank credit facility but also made payments of $6.4 million against the credit facility.&#160; The Company realized $200,000 from the tax benefit arising from the exercise of stock-based awards during fiscal year 2015.&#160; &#160; The Company has been authorized by its Board of Directors to repurchase up to $5 million worth of shares of its common stock for treasury whenever appropriate opportunities arise but it has neither a fixed repurchase plan nor commitments to purchase additional shares in the future.&#160; As of the end of fiscal year 2016, the Company has repurchased approximately $4 million of its common stock out of the $5 million authorization.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 8PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The Company will continue to expend resources to develop, improve and acquire products for space applications, guidance and targeting systems, and communication systems which management believes will result in future growth and continued profitability.&#160; During fiscal year 2017,where possible, the Company will secure partial customer funding for its R&amp;D efforts but is targeting to spend its own funds at a rate of up to 10% of revenues to achieve its development goals.&#160; Internally generated cash will be adequate to fund these development efforts.&#160; The Company may also pursue acquisitions to expand its range of products and may use internally generated cash and external funding in connection with such acquisitions.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	The Company&#8217;s international business is subject to changes in demand or pricing resulting from fluctuations in currency exchange rates, primarily in the Euro to U.S. Dollar exchange rate and in the Chinese Renminbi to U.S. Dollar exchange rate.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-LEFT: 22.5PT">
<U>
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 8PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The Company does not have any off&#8209;balance sheet arrangements, other than operating leases, that have or are reasonably likely to have a current or future effect on the Company&#8217;s financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital resources that is material to investors.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	18
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage19"></A>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEHEADER" STYLE="WIDTH: 100%">
<A HREF="#FREQUENCYELE10K043016_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 8PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 8PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	As of April 30, 2016, the Company's consolidated backlog amounted to approximately $32 million as compared to approximately $37 million at the beginning of the fiscal year. (See Item 1).&#160; Approximately 75% of this backlog is expected to be filled during the Company&#8217;s fiscal year ending April 30, 2017.&#160; The Company excludes from backlog any contracts or awards for which it has not received authorization to proceed.&#160; On fixed price contracts, the Company excludes any unfunded portion.&#160; The Company expects any partially funded contracts to become fully funded over time and will add the additional funding to its backlog at that time.&#160; The backlog is subject to change by reason of several factors including possible cancellation of orders, change orders, terms of the contracts and other factors beyond the Company's control.&#160; Accordingly, the backlog is not necessarily indicative of the revenues or profits (losses) which may be realized when the results of such contracts are reported.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The Company&#8217;s liquidity is adequate to meet its operating and investment needs through at least July 29, 2017.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<U>
	RECENT ACCOUNTING PRONOUNCEMENTS
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 1.45PT; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In March 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#8220;FASB&#8221;) amended the existing accounting standards for stock-based compensation, Accounting Standards Update (&#8220;ASU&#8221;) 2016-09,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Compensation-Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting
</FONT>
	. The amendments impact several aspects of accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the income tax consequences, forfeitures, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities, and classification on the statement of cash flows.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	This guidance requires a mix of prospective, modified retrospective, and retrospective transition to all annual and interim periods presented and is effective for the Company beginning in fiscal 2018. The Company has not determined the full impact of implementation of this standard, but does not expect it will have a material effect on the Company&#8217;s financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 1.45PT; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02 Leases (Topic 842). The objective of the update is to increase transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and disclosing key information about leasing arrangements.&#160;&#160;The amendments of the ASU 2016-02 are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 31, 2018 and early adoption is permitted.&#160;&#160;The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17 (&#8220;ASU 2015-17&#8221;),
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes
</FONT>
	. The amendments in ASU 2015-17 seek to simplify the presentation of deferred income taxes and require that deferred tax liabilities and assets be classified as noncurrent in a classified statement of financial position. ASU 2015-17 is effective for financial statements issued for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods, with early application permitted for all entities as of the beginning of an interim or annual reporting period. The Company has not determined the full impact of implementation of this standard, but believes it will not be material to net income.&#160; The Company believes that the main impact of adoption of the standard will be the reclassification of current deferred tax assets to an increase in noncurrent deferred tax assets for the period ending April 30, 2018.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-11,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Inventory
</FONT>
	&#160;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	(Topic 330): Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory
</FONT>
	(&#8220;ASU 2015-11&#8221;) which changes the measurement principle for inventory from the lower of cost or market to the lower of cost or&#160;net realizable value.&#160; ASU 2015-11 defines net realizable value as estimated selling prices in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal and transportation.&#160; The new guidance must be applied on a prospective basis and is effective for periods beginning after December 15, 2016, with early adoption permitted.&#160; The Company is currently evaluating the effect that the new guidance will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-15
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	, Presentation of Financial Statements &#8211; Going Concern (Subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity&#8217;s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern (&#8220;ASU 2014-15&#8221;),
</FONT>
	which is effective for annual periods after December 15, 2016 and for annual periods and interim periods
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	&#160;
</FONT>
	thereafter. Early application is permitted.&#160; Under ASU 2014-15, entities will be required to formally assess their ability to continue as a going concern and provide disclosures under certain circumstances.&#160; While current practice regarding such disclosures is often guided by U.S. auditing standards, the new standard explicitly requires the assessment at interim and annual periods, and provides management with its own disclosure guidance.&#160; The standard can be adopted early.&#160; The company is currently assessing the impact that adopting these new assessment and disclosure requirements will have on its financial statements and footnote disclosures.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	19
</FONT>
</DIV>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	.&#160; ASU 2014-09 eliminates most of the existing industry-specific revenue recognition guidance and significantly expands related disclosures.&#160; The required disclosures will include both quantitative and qualitative information about the amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue from contracts with customers and the significant judgments used.&#160; Entities can retrospectively apply ASU 2014-09 or use an alternative transition method.&#160; In July 2015, the FASB approved a one-year deferral of the effective date of this ASU.&#160; Although the amending ASU has not yet been issued, since it will be amended, this ASU is effective for public companies for annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2017 and for the Company, must be adopted for its fiscal year 2019 beginning on May 1, 2018.&#160; The Company is in the process of determining the effect that ASU 2014-09 may have on its financial statements
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #FF0000">
	.
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	OTHER MATTERS
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.3PT">
	The financial information reported herein is not necessarily indicative of future operating results or of the future financial condition of the Company.&#160; Except as noted, management is unaware of any impending transactions or internal events that are likely to have a material adverse effect on results from operations.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<U>
	INFLATION
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 22.5PT">
	During fiscal year 2016, as in fiscal year 2015, the impact of inflation on the Company's business has not been materially significant.
</DIV>

	Item 8.&#160; Financial Statements and Supplementary Data

<EFX_AUDITORS_OPINION>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDITORS_OPINION"></A>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
<A NAME="FREQUENCYELE10K043016_HTM_REPORT">
<!--ANCHOR-->
</A>
	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	Board of Directors and Shareholders of
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
<BR>
</FONT>
	Frequency Electronics, Inc.
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Frequency Electronics, Inc. and Subsidiaries (the "Company") as of April 30, 2016 and 2015, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, cash flows and changes in stockholders' equity for each of the years then ended.&#160; The financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.&#160; Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).&#160; Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.&#160; The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.&#160; Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting.&#160; Accordingly, we express no such opinion.&#160; An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.&#160; We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Frequency Electronics, Inc. and Subsidiaries as of April&#160;30, 2016 and 2015, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years then ended, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV>
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 72PT">
<U>
	/s/ EisnerAmper LLP
</U>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	EisnerAmper LLP
</DIV>

<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	21
</FONT>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</DIV>
<EFX_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT>
<A NAME="FIS_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT"></A>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
<A NAME="FREQUENCYELE10K043016_HTM_NOTES">
<!--ANCHOR-->
</A>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	April 30, 2016 and 2015
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	1.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
<U>
	Summary of Accounting Policies
</U>
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD">
	Principles of Consolidation
</FONT>
	:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Frequency Electronics, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries (the "Company" or "Registrant").&#160; References to &#8220;FEI&#8221; are to the parent company alone and do not refer to any of its subsidiaries.&#160; The Company is principally engaged in the design, development and manufacture of precision time and frequency control products and components for microwave integrated circuit applications.&#160; See Note 13 for information regarding the Company&#8217;s FEI-NY (which includes the subsidiaries FEI Government Systems, Inc., FEI Communications, Inc., Frequency Electronics, Inc. Asia (&#8220;FEI-Asia&#8221;) and FEI-Elcom Tech, Inc. (&#8220;FEI-Elcom&#8221;)), Gillam-FEI, and FEI-Zyfer business segments.&#160; Intercompany accounts and significant intercompany transactions are eliminated in consolidation.&#160; To accommodate the different fiscal periods of Gillam-FEI, the Company recognizes its share of net income or loss on a one month lag.&#160; Any material events which may occur during the intervening month at Gillam-FEI will be accounted for in the consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	These financial statements have been prepared in conformity with United States generally accepted accounting principles (&#8220;U.S. GAAP&#8221;) and require management to make estimates and assumptions that affect amounts reported and disclosed in the financial statements and related notes.&#160; Actual results could differ from these estimates.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Cash Equivalents:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company considers certificates of deposit and other highly liquid investments with maturities of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.&#160; The Company places its temporary cash investments with high credit quality financial institutions.&#160; Such investments may at times be in excess of the FDIC and SIPC insurance limits.&#160; No losses have been experienced on such investments.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Marketable Securities:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Marketable securities consist of investments in common stocks, including exchange-traded funds, corporate debt securities and debt securities of U.S. Government agencies.&#160; All marketable securities were held in the custody of financial institutions; three institutions at April 30, 2016 and 2015.&#160; Investments in debt and equity securities are categorized as available for sale and are carried at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from income and recorded directly to stockholders' equity.&#160; The Company recognizes gains or losses when securities are sold using the specific identification method.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Losses from uncollectible accounts receivable are provided for by utilizing the allowance for doubtful accounts method based upon management&#8217;s estimate of uncollectible accounts.&#160; Management analyzes accounts receivable and the potential for bad debts, customer concentrations, credit worthiness, current economic trends and changes in customer payment terms when evaluating the amount recorded for the allowance for doubtful accounts.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Property, Plant and Equipment:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost and include interest on funds borrowed to finance construction.&#160; Expenditures for renewals and betterments are capitalized; maintenance and repairs are charged to income when incurred.&#160; When fixed assets are sold or retired, the cost and related accumulated depreciation and amortization are eliminated from the respective accounts and any gain or loss is credited or charged to income.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	If events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of a long-lived asset may not be recoverable, the Company estimates the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset and its eventual disposition.&#160; If the sum of the expected future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges) is less than the carrying amount of the long-lived asset, an impairment loss is recognized.&#160; To date, no impairment losses have been recognized.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	27
</FONT>
</DIV>

	FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES

	April 30, 2016 and 2015
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD">
	Inventories
</FONT>
	:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Inventories, which consist of finished goods, work-in-process, raw materials and components, are accounted for at the lower of cost (specific and average) or market.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Depreciation and Amortization:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Depreciation of fixed assets is computed on the straight-line method based upon the estimated useful lives of the assets (40 years for buildings and 3 to 10 years for other depreciable assets).&#160; Leasehold improvements and equipment acquired under capital leases are amortized on the straight-line method over the shorter of the term of the lease or the useful life of the related asset.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Amortization of identifiable intangible assets is based upon the expected lives of the assets and is recorded at a rate which approximates the Company&#8217;s utilization of the assets.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Intangible Assets:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Intangible assets consist of the ISO 9000 certification arising from the acquisition of FEI-Elcom in the assignment of fair value to its acquired assets including intangibles.&#160; The certification is valued at fair value and was amortized over the estimated useful life of 3 years from the date of acquisition.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Goodwill:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company records goodwill as the excess of purchase price over the fair value of identifiable net assets acquired.&#160; Goodwill is tested for impairment on at least an annual basis at year end.&#160; When it is determined that the carrying value of goodwill may not be recoverable, the Company writes down the goodwill to an amount commensurate with the revised value of the acquired assets.&#160; The Company measures impairment based on revenue projections, recent transactions involving similar businesses and price/revenue multiples at which they were bought and sold, price/revenue multiples of competitors, and the present market value of publicly-traded companies in the Company&#8217;s industry.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Revenue and Cost Recognition:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Revenues under larger, long-term contracts, which generally require billings based on achievement of milestones rather than delivery of product, are reported in operating results using the percentage of completion method.&#160; For U.S. Government and other fixed-price contracts that require initial design and development of the product, revenue is recognized on the cost-to-cost method.&#160; Under this method, revenue is recorded based upon the ratio that incurred costs bear to total estimated contract costs with related cost of sales recorded as the costs are incurred.&#160; Costs and estimated earnings in excess of billings on uncompleted contracts, net of billings on uncompleted contracts in excess of costs and estimated earnings, are included in current assets.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	On production-type orders, revenue is recorded as units are delivered with the related cost of sales recognized on each shipment based upon a percentage of estimated final program costs.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Changes in job performance on long-term and production-type orders may result in revisions to costs and revenue and are recognized in the period in which revisions are determined to be required.&#160; Provisions for the full amount of anticipated losses are made in the period in which they become determinable.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	For customer orders in the Company&#8217;s subsidiaries, and smaller contracts or orders in the other business segments, sales of products and services to customers are reported in operating results upon shipment of the product or performance of the services pursuant to terms of the customer order.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Contract costs include all direct material, direct labor costs, manufacturing overhead and other direct costs related to contract performance.&#160; Selling, general and administrative costs are charged to expense as incurred.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	In accordance with industry practice, inventoried costs contain amounts relating to contracts and programs with long production cycles, a portion of which will not be realized within one year.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD">
	&#160;
</FONT>
	Program costs for which production-level orders cannot be determined as probable are written down in the period in which that assessment is made.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	28
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAK" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER: ALWAYS">
<HR STYLE="BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; HEIGHT: 2PX; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; COLOR: #000000; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN: 4PX 0PX; BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; WIDTH: 100%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #000000" NOSHADE="NOSHADE">
</DIV>

<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEHEADER" STYLE="WIDTH: 100%">
<A HREF="#FREQUENCYELE10K043016_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#160; -&#160; Continued
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	April 30, 2016 and 2015
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
	Comprehensive Income:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income.&#160; Other comprehensive income includes changes in unrealized gains or losses, net of tax, on securities available for sale during the year and the effects of foreign currency translation adjustments.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
	Research and Development Expenses:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company engages in research and development activities to identify new applications for its core technologies, to improve existing products and to improve manufacturing processes to achieve cost reductions and manufacturing efficiencies.&#160; Research and development costs include direct labor, manufacturing overhead, direct materials and contracted services.&#160; Such costs are expensed as incurred.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Income Taxes:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company recognizes deferred tax liabilities and assets based on the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial statements or tax returns.&#160; Under this method, deferred tax liabilities and assets are determined based on the difference between the financial statement and tax bases of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse.&#160; Valuation allowances are established and adjusted when necessary to increase or reduce deferred tax assets to the amount expected to be realized.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company analyzes its tax positions under accounting standards which prescribe recognition thresholds that must be met before a tax benefit is recognized in the financial statements and provides guidance on de-recognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure, and transition.&#160; An entity may only recognize or continue to recognize tax positions that meet a "more likely than not" threshold.&#160; When and if the Company were to recognize interest or penalties related to income taxes, it would be reported net of the federal tax benefit in the tax provision.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Earnings Per Share:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Basic earnings per share are computed by dividing net earnings by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding.&#160; Diluted earnings per share are computed by dividing net earnings by the sum of the weighted average number of shares of common stock and the if-converted effect of unexercised stock options and stock appreciation rights.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Fair Values of Financial Instruments:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Cash and cash equivalents, short-term credit obligations, long term debt and cash surrender value are reflected in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets at amounts considered by management to reasonably approximate fair value based upon the nature of the instrument and current market conditions.&#160; Management is not aware of any factors that would significantly affect the value of these amounts.&#160; The Company also has an investment in a privately-held company, Morion, Inc. (&#8220;Morion&#8221;).&#160; The Company is unable to reasonably estimate a fair value for this investment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
	Foreign Operations and Foreign Currency Adjustments:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company maintains manufacturing operations in Belgium and the People&#8217;s Republic of China. The Company is vulnerable to currency risks in these countries.&#160; The local currency is the functional currency of each of the Company&#8217;s non-U.S. subsidiaries.&#160; No foreign currency gains or losses are recorded on intercompany transactions since they are effected at current rates of exchange.&#160; The results of operations of foreign subsidiaries, when translated into U.S. dollars, reflect the average rates of exchange for the periods presented.&#160; The balance sheets of foreign subsidiaries, except for equity accounts which are translated at historical rates, are translated into U.S. dollars at the rates of exchange in effect on the date of the balance sheet.&#160; As a result, similar results in local currency can vary upon translation into U.S. dollars if exchange rates fluctuate significantly from one period to the next.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Equity-based Compensation:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company values its share-based payment transactions using the Black-Scholes valuation model. Such value is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the service period of the awards, which is generally the vesting period, net of estimated forfeitures.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	29
</FONT>
</DIV>

</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT">
	1.50% and 2.38
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" NOWRAP="NOWRAP">
	%
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; WIDTH: 47%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
	Expected lives
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&#160;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT">
	5.0 years
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" NOWRAP="NOWRAP">
	&#160;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&#160;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" COLSPAN="2">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT">
	5.0 and 8.5 years
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; WIDTH: 1%; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #FFFFFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM" NOWRAP="NOWRAP">
	&#160;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-TOP: 2PT; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-TOP: 2PT; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The expected life assumption was determined based on the Company&#8217;s historical experience as well as the term of recent SAR agreements.&#160; The expected volatility assumption was based on the historical volatility of the Company&#8217;s common stock.&#160; The dividend yield assumption was determined based upon the Company&#8217;s past history of dividend payments and the Company&#8217;s current decision to suspend payment of dividends.&#160; The risk-free interest rate assumption was determined using the implied yield currently available for zero-coupon U.S. Government issues with a remaining term equal to the expected life of the stock options or SARs.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
	Concentration of Credit Risk
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Financial instruments, which potentially subject the Company to concentration of credit risk, consist principally of cash and cash equivalents and trade receivables.&#160; The Company maintains accounts at several commercial banks at which the balances exceed Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation limits.&#160; The Company has not experienced any losses on such amounts.&#160; Concentration of credit risk with respect to trade receivables is generally diversified due to the large number of entities comprising the Company&#8217;s customer base and their dispersion across geographic areas principally within the United States.&#160; The Company routinely addresses the financial strength of its customers and, as a consequence, believes that its receivable credit risk exposure is limited.&#160; The Company does not require customers to post collateral.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
	New Accounting Pronouncements:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 1.45PT; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In March 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#8220;FASB&#8221;) amended the existing accounting standards for stock-based compensation, Accounting Standards Update (&#8220;ASU&#8221;) 2016-09,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Compensation-Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting
</FONT>
	. The amendments impact several aspects of accounting for share-based payment transactions, including the income tax consequences, forfeitures, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities, and classification on the statement of cash flows.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	This guidance requires a mix of prospective, modified retrospective, and retrospective transition to all annual and interim periods presented and is effective for the Company beginning in fiscal 2018. The Company has not determined the full impact of implementation of this standard, but does not expect it will have a material effect on the Company&#8217;s financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 1.45PT; TEXT-INDENT: 36PT">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02 Leases (Topic 842). The objective of the update is to increase transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and disclosing key information about leasing arrangements.&#160;&#160;The amendments of the ASU 2016-02 are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 31, 2018 and early adoption is permitted.&#160;&#160;The Company is currently evaluating the impact of this standard on our consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17 (&#8220;ASU 2015-17&#8221;),
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes
</FONT>
	. The amendments in ASU 2015-17 seek to simplify the presentation of deferred income taxes and require that deferred tax liabilities and assets be classified as noncurrent in a classified statement of financial position. ASU 2015-17 is effective for financial statements issued for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods, with early application permitted for all entities as of the beginning of an interim or annual reporting period. The Company has not determined the full impact of implementation of this standard, but believes it will not be material to net income.&#160; The Company believes that the main impact of adoption of the standard will be the reclassification of current deferred tax assets to an increase in noncurrent deferred tax assets for the period ending April 30, 2018.
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEBREAKAREA" STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 10PT; CLEAR: BOTH; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGEFOOTER">
</DIV>
<DIV ID="DSPFPAGENUMBERAREA" STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<FONT ID="DSPFPAGENUMBER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: NORMAL; FONT-STYLE: NORMAL">
	30
</FONT>
</DIV>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT">
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#160; -&#160; Continued
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	April 30, 2016 and 2015
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-11,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	Inventory
</FONT>
	&#160;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	(Topic 330): Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory
</FONT>
	(&#8220;ASU 2015-11&#8221;) which changes the measurement principle for inventory from the lower of cost or market to the lower of cost or&#160;net realizable value.&#160; ASU 2015-11 defines net realizable value as estimated selling prices in the ordinary course of business, less reasonably predictable costs of completion, disposal and transportation.&#160; The new guidance must be applied on a prospective basis and is effective for periods beginning after December 15, 2016, with early adoption permitted.&#160; The Company is currently evaluating the effect that the new guidance will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-15
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	, Presentation of Financial Statements &#8211; Going Concern (Subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity&#8217;s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern (&#8220;ASU 2014-15&#8221;),
</FONT>
	which is effective for annual periods after December 15, 2016 and for annual periods and interim periods
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	&#160;
</FONT>
	thereafter. Early application is permitted.&#160; Under ASU 2014-15, entities will be required to formally assess their ability to continue as a going concern and provide disclosures under certain circumstances.&#160; While current practice regarding such disclosures is often guided by U.S. auditing standards, the new standard explicitly requires the assessment at interim and annual periods, and provides management with its own disclosure guidance.&#160; The standard can be adopted early.&#160; The company is currently assessing the impact that adopting these new assessment and disclosure requirements will have on its financial statements and footnote disclosures.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000; FONT-STYLE: ITALIC">
	, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #000000">
	.&#160; ASU 2014-09 eliminates most of the existing industry-specific revenue recognition guidance and significantly expands related disclosures.&#160; The required disclosures will include both quantitative and qualitative information about the amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue from contracts with customers and the significant judgments used.&#160; Entities can retrospectively apply ASU 2014-09 or use an alternative transition method.&#160; In July 2015, the FASB approved a one-year deferral of the effective date of this ASU.&#160; Although the amending ASU has not yet been issued, since it will be amended, this ASU is effective for public companies for annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2017 and for the Company, must be adopted for its fiscal year 2019 beginning on May 1, 2018.&#160; The Company is in the process of determining the effect that ASU 2014-09 may have on its financial statements
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; COLOR: #FF0000">
	.
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
	2.
</FONT>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Dilutive securities consist of unexercised stock options and stock appreciation rights (&#8220;SARS&#8221;).&#160; The computation of diluted shares outstanding excludes those options and SARS with an exercise price in excess of the average market price of the Company&#8217;s common shares during the periods presented.&#160; The inclusion of such options and SARS in the computation of earnings per share would have been antidilutive.&#160; For the years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015, the number of excluded options and SARS were 388,625 and 271,500, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.5PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
	3.
</FONT>
<FONT ID="TRGRRTFTOHTMLTAB" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PX; DISPLAY: INLINE-BLOCK; WIDTH: 22.5PT">
	&#160;
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
<U>
	Costs and Estimated Earnings in Excess of Billings
</U>
</FONT>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	At April 30, 2016 and 2015, costs and estimated earnings in excess of billings, net, consist of the following:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT; TEXT-INDENT: 31.7PT">
	&#160;
</DIV>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; FONT-WEIGHT: BOLD; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT; TEXT-INDENT: 27.35PT">
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#160; -&#160; Continued
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN-RIGHT: 28.8PT">
	April 30, 2016 and 2015
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Such amounts represent revenue recognized on long-term contracts that had not been billed at the balance sheet dates or represent a liability for amounts billed in excess of the revenue recognized.&#160; Amounts are billed to customers pursuant to contract terms.&#160; In general, the recorded amounts will be billed and collected or revenue recognized within twelve months of the balance sheet date.&#160; Revenue on these long-term contracts is accounted for on the percentage of completion basis.&#160; During the years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015, revenue recognized under percentage of completion contracts was approximately $32.5 million and $46.8 million, respectively.&#160; If contract losses are anticipated, costs and estimated earnings in excess of billings are reduced for the full amount of such losses when they are determinable.&#160; Total anticipated contract losses at April 30, 2016 and 2015 were approximately $450,000 and $400,000, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF">
	4.
</FONT>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	&#160;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	As of April 30, 2016 and 2015, approximately $35.3 million and $32.0 million, respectively, of total inventory is located in the United States, approximately $5.0 million and $5.4 million, respectively, is located in Belgium and approximately $1.0 million and $0.8 million, respectively, is located in China.&#160; The company buys inventory in bulk quantities which may be used over significant time periods; due to its nature the inventory does not deteriorate.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 5PT; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; MARGIN-RIGHT: 24.3PT">

	5.

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Depreciation and amortization expense for the years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015 was $2,660,000 and $2,828,000, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	Maintenance and repairs charged to operations for the years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015 was approximately $611,000 and $1,017,000, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company leases its Long Island, New York headquarters building at an annual rent of $800,000 following the Company&#8217;s exercise of its option to renew the lease for a second 5-year period.&#160; The lease will end in January 2019.&#160; Under the terms of the lease, the Company is required to pay its proportionate share of real estate taxes, insurance and other charges.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 4PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	In addition, the Company&#8217;s subsidiaries in New Jersey, China, France and California lease their office and manufacturing facilities.&#160; FEI-Elcom leases 32,000 square feet of office and manufacturing space at current monthly rental of approximately $40,000 through the end of the lease which expires in March 2018.&#160; The lease for the FEI-Asia facility is for a one-year term with monthly rent of $5,000 through February 2017.&#160; FEI-Zyfer leases office and manufacturing space encompassing 27,850 square feet.&#160; Monthly rental payments are currently $31,200 for the remaining 16 months of the lease term.&#160; Satel-FEI, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Gillam-FEI, occupies office space under a 9-year lease, cancelable after three years, at an approximate rate of $1,000 per month.
</DIV>

	Rent expense under operating leases was approximately $1.5 million for both fiscal years ended April 30, 2016 and 2015.&#160; The Company records rent expense on its New York building and FEI-Zyfer facility on the straight-line method over the lives of the respective leases.&#160; As a result, as of April 30, 2016 and 2015, the Company&#8217;s balance sheet includes deferred rent payable of approximately $214,000 and $290,000, respectively, which will be recognized over the respective rental periods.

	April 30, 2016 and 2015

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM: 2PT; FONT-SIZE: 10PT; FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN', TIMES, SERIF; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY; TEXT-INDENT: 18PT">
	The Company regularly reviews its investment portfolio to identify and evaluate investments that have indications of possible impairment.&#160; The Company does not believe that its investments in marketable securities with unrealized losses at April 30, 2016 are other-than-temporary due to market volatility of the security&#8217;s fair value, analysts&#8217; expectations and the Company&#8217;s ability to hold the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recoveries in market value.
</DIV>

	&#160;
